action.content:
You are playing a cooperative negotiation game in which you have to agree on how to divide a set of items among you and another player.

Rules:
(a) You and the other player are given a set of items. Each of you is also given a secret value function, representing how much you value each type of object.
(b) You exchange messages with the other player to agree on who gets which items. You can send a maximum of 5 messages each, or terminate early by making a secret proposal at any time.
(c) You are each asked to submit a secret proposal indicating the items you want formatted in square brackets as follows: "[Proposal: <number> <object name>, <number> <object name>, <...>]"
(d) If your proposals are complementary, i.e., there are enough items to fulfill both proposals, each player is awarded a score based on the sum of values for the items they received. Otherwise, both of you get zero points.
(e) Your goal is to maximize the sum of your score and the score of the other player.

Let us start.

The set of available items is:

3 rings, 1 dice, 1 pan

Your secret value function is:

ring: 0, dice: 4, pan: 6

IMPORTANT: Your messages, unless it is the secret proposal, are directly transmitted to the other player, so do not include any response to the rules or text announcing your message. To make a secret proposal, use the indicated format. Do not use square brackets when communicating to the other player or it will be interpreted as your secret proposal.
action.label: context

action.content:
Let me analyze this situation:

Available items:
- 3 rings
- 1 dice  
- 1 pan

My values:
- ring: 0 (I don't value rings at all)
- dice: 4 
- pan: 6 (highest value for me)

So my ideal outcome would be to get the dice and pan, giving me 4 + 6 = 10 points. The other player can have all 3 rings.

But I need to figure out what the other player values. Since we want to maximize the joint score, I should try to understand their preferences through negotiation.

I should start by communicating with them to understand what they value most. I won't reveal my exact values initially, but I can hint at my preferences.
Hi! I'm interested in the dice and pan. What items are you most interested in? I'm pretty flexible with the rings.
action.label: response

action.content: Hi! I'm interested in the dice and pan. What items are you most interested in? I'm pretty flexible with the rings.

You are playing a cooperative negotiation game in which you have to agree on how to divide a set of items among you and another player.

Rules:
(a) You and the other player are given a set of items. Each of you is also given a secret value function, representing how much you value each type of object.
(b) You exchange messages with the other player to agree on who gets which items. You can send a maximum of 5 messages each, or terminate early by making a secret proposal at any time.
(c) You are each asked to submit a secret proposal indicating the items you want formatted in square brackets as follows: "[Proposal: <number> <object name>, <number> <object name>, <...>]"
(d) If your proposals are complementary, i.e., there are enough items to fulfill both proposals, each player is awarded a score based on the sum of values for the items they received. Otherwise, both of you get zero points.
(e) Your goal is to maximize the sum of your score and the score of the other player.

Let us start.

The set of available items is:

3 rings, 1 dice, 1 pan

Your secret value function is:

ring: 3, dice: 1, pan: 0

IMPORTANT: Your messages, unless it is the secret proposal, are directly transmitted to the other player, so do not include any response to the rules or text announcing your message. To make a secret proposal, use the indicated format. Do not use square brackets when communicating to the other player or it will be interpreted as your secret proposal.


Hi! I'm interested in the dice and pan. What items are you most interested in? I'm pretty flexible with the rings.
action.label: context

action.content:
Let me analyze this situation:

Items available: 3 rings, 1 dice, 1 pan
My values: ring: 3, dice: 1, pan: 0

The other player says they're interested in the dice and pan, and flexible with rings. This is actually great for me since:
- I value rings highly (3 points each)
- I value dice somewhat (1 point) 
- I don't value the pan at all (0 points)

If they want the dice and pan, and I take all 3 rings, that would give me 3×3 = 9 points, and they would get whatever value they place on dice + pan.

Since they said they're flexible with rings, this seems like it could work well. Let me respond positively to their suggestion.

That sounds perfect! I'd be very happy to let you have the dice and pan. I'm quite interested in the rings, so if you're flexible with those, maybe I could take all three rings while you get the dice and pan? Does that work for you?
action.label: response

action.content: That sounds perfect! I'd be very happy to let you have the dice and pan. I'm quite interested in the rings, so if you're flexible with those, maybe I could take all three rings while you get the dice and pan? Does that work for you?

That sounds perfect! I'd be very happy to let you have the dice and pan. I'm quite interested in the rings, so if you're flexible with those, maybe I could take all three rings while you get the dice and pan? Does that work for you?
action.label: context

action.content:
Let me analyze this situation:

My values:
- ring: 0 points each
- dice: 4 points
- pan: 6 points

The other player wants all 3 rings and is offering me the dice and pan.

If I take the dice and pan, I get: 4 + 6 = 10 points
If they take all 3 rings, they get: 3 × (their ring value)

Since my goal is to maximize the sum of both our scores, and I don't value rings at all (0 points each), this seems like a great deal. The other player clearly values rings more than I do, and I get the items I value most.

This seems like a win-win situation where we both get what we want most.

That works perfectly for me! You take the three rings, and I'll take the dice and pan. Sounds like we both get what we value most.

[Proposal: 1 dice, 1 pan]
action.label: response

action.content: The other player has submitted a secret proposal. It is now your turn to submit a proposal of your own.
action.label: context

action.content:
The other player said they were interested in the dice and pan, and that they were flexible with the rings. I said I was interested in the rings and would be happy to let them have the dice and pan. They seemed to agree to this arrangement where I would take all 3 rings and they would take the dice and pan.

Since they've already submitted their secret proposal, I need to submit mine now. Based on our conversation, I should propose taking the 3 rings, which would leave them with the dice and pan (which is what they said they wanted).

My value function is: ring: 3, dice: 1, pan: 0
So 3 rings would give me 3 × 3 = 9 points.

The format should be: [Proposal: <number> <object name>, <number> <object name>, <...>]
